key_insight: A single pre-trained AlphaTensor-Quantum model can be reused (without retraining) to optimize a wide variety of quantum circuits, achieving larger T-count reductions and demonstrating broad generalizability and efficiency.
problem_solved: High T-counts increase fault-tolerant quantum resource costs and many optimizers are specialized or require retraining for new circuit families; this work addresses the need for a general, reusable optimizer that reduces T-cost across diverse circuits.
method: Apply a pre-trained AlphaTensor-Quantum model directly to new circuit instances to search for T-reducing rewrites and decompositions without retraining.
Combine model-guided transformations with classical circuit decomposition and local rewrite heuristics to produce lower-T implementations.
Benchmark across a broad set of circuit families to quantify T-count reductions and validate generalizability and efficiency.
impact: Makes quantum circuit optimization more practical and scalable by lowering fault-tolerant resource requirements without repeated model training, enabling faster iteration and reduced hardware cost for quantum ML and algorithm development.
visual_elements: Before/after bar chart showing T-count reductions across multiple circuit families (percentage and absolute drop).
Pipeline diagram: pre-trained AlphaTensor-Quantum -> apply to circuit -> model-guided rewrites -> optimized circuit.
Benchmark heatmap comparing T-count savings per circuit type and runtime overhead.
Annotated quantum circuit diagram highlighting removed/reduced T gates and transformed subcircuits.
paper_title: Reusability report: Optimizing T count in general quantum circuits with AlphaTensor-Quantum
paper_authors: Remmy Zen, Maximilian NÃ¤gele, Florian Marquardt
